pros:
The company as a whole is very good about keeping the toxicity common to large corporations at a minimum. Because of its heritage as a software engineering company more than what's considered a "tech company" today, there's a very healthy engineering culture with a relatively low level of meddling by upper and middle management in most parts of the company. Employee benefits are very strong and the company is excellent at integrating a remote and geo-diverse workforce, even prior to the pandemic. The headquarters facility is well-run and facility staff (from building operations to kitchens to security and safety) are fantastic.

Incredibly smart people work here and for the most part embody the company's stated value of bringing their genuine selves to work.
cons:
Compensation and growth opportunity is not commensurate with the company's stated aims for employees. After a decade of record-breaking years, employee compensation rises quite modestly.

The engineering heritage of the company is eroding a bit. Offices with doors that close and allow engineers to think about problems and solve them were torn out and replaced with open plan spaces that are noisy, busy, and unproductive.

Reorgs are increasing in frequency -- something of a red flag -- and often disruptive.

Adobe has great benefits, perks, and everything you'd expect a big tech company to provide to their employees. They use these tools to convey how much they care for their employees, which can translate to folks staying for a long time (there are many people at Adobe who stay for 10/20 and in some cases 30+ years).

Most of the folks in management genuinely care about their employees and try their best to position them for long-term success at the company.

The companies products and generosity, in most cases, really help people. For example, discounted products for teachers/students, donations to organizations aimed at progressing our society forward, volunteer-based opportunities and compensation related to that (motivating employee participation), and more.

Throughout my time at Adobe I was given opportunities to grow in my role, take on additional responsibilities, and have my needs supported by my Manager(s). As an employee - I can genuinely say that I enjoyed my time with the company and would recommend it to anyone looking to pursue a career with a large technology company.
cons:
Lack of a cohesive business vision and stability in almost every revenue-generating product. High attrition particularly within leadership, leading to constant change in priorities/strategies in growing each business. As a result of this attrition, lots of folks look to climb the corporate ladder, getting in the way of product growth, delivery, and innovation. Great benefits and perks often motivate folks to coast, rather than constantly achieving and resetting the bar for success.

The CC suite, while still an industry leader, is lagging in growth and becoming higher in cost - all while rivals are inching closer to the capabilities CC can provide, for a more-reasonable cost.

The Digital Marketing business oftentimes doesn't live up to customer commitments and ends up doing a lot of cleanup once their software is implemented.

Document Cloud seems to be the only shining light as growth was driven towards this product during the pandemic, but that growth has slowed and the market for this type of software is incredibly saturated.

While Shantanyu (the CEO of Adobe) makes 36+ million dollars per year, the company pretends that they can't afford to properly value their employees who are not grossly overpaid. 

Adobe calls their HR team ERC (employee resource center). However, they are still the same ruthless thugs who will do everything they can to maintain the status quo and ensure they save the company as much money as possible.
